Page.title: Changelog
Page._content:
• Added
  • Updated
  • Fixed
  • Todo
TODO, 2017

Version 2.X.X/

TODO Release

  • Workshop area on website.
  • Versioned documentation.
  • Improve unit tests to 99% of coverage.
January, 2017

Version 2.0.0

Release

  • Release artifcats to m2 release.
  • Added native Application Context Resource
  • Added Injector Strategy to customize inversion of control
  • Added Resource injection with @Resource for non components
  • Improved Environment Exception and standardized error codes
  • Improved CommonsConfiguration with Apache Configurations
  • Improved unit tests to more than 85% of coverage.
  • Improved performance of Environment Container
  • Restructured Environment Container
November, 2016

Version 1.1.0

Release Candidate

  • Discontinued release 1.1.0, and moved to Branch 1.1.0 and prepared to release 2.0.0
  • Release of 1.1.0
  • Added Parameterized retention to superclass types
  • Improved code coverage
  • Removed Serializer default interfaces from core project
  • Moved Collections features to jspare-collections project
June, 2016

Version 1.0.0

Release

  • Release of 1.0.0
  • 50% Test Coverage
  • Custom Derivates Collections
  • MySupport extension for simple injection at any class
  • Injection with @Inject Annotation
  • Resource File Loader
  • Json Components using Gson
  • Apache Commons Configuration to Parameterized Apps
  • Bundle Packages into Bootstrap
  • Environment Builder into Bootstrap
  • Environment Container
  • Powered by Lombok Project
  • Application Bootsrap Support
    • \

Page.title: Get Started
Page._content:
First steps

Starting with JSpare Core Container

Dependencies

Follow the required dependencies for start with JSpare Core Container

Maven

<dependency>
	<groupId>org.jspare</groupId>
	<artifactId>jspare-core</artifactId>
	<version>2.0.0</version>
</dependency>
Gradle

dependencies {
    compile "org.jspare:jspare-core:2.0.0"
}

Structuring a project

Example basics of how should be the default structure of your project, later on we will deal with all the conventions.

  • org.jspare.samples Default package
    • model Package with models
      • Car.java Sample model
    • api API sample package
      • CarApi.java Interfaces of APIs
      • CarApiImpl.java Impl for CarApi interface
    • application The application impls
      • Consumer.java Class responsible for consume apis
    • Bootstrap.java Bootstrap of project

Abuse of components!

Write your applications using container, surely your application will get more organized and you were unpacking things.


package org.jspare.samples.api;

import java.util.List;

import org.jspare.core.annotation.Component;
import org.jspare.samples.model.Car;

@Component
public interface CarApi {

  List search();
}

Follow the convetions, it will help you!

The JSpare Core Container, have some conventions for help with your codding. Below you will see a convention for standard implementation of a component.



package org.jspare.samples.model;

public class Car {

  private String name;
  
  private int year;
  
  public Car(String name, int year) {
    super();
    this.name = name;
    this.year = year;
  }

  public String getName() {
    return name;
  }

  public void setName(String name) {
    this.name = name;
  }

  public int getYear() {
    return year;
  }

  public void setYear(int year) {
    this.year = year;
  }
  
  public void print(){
    
    System.out.println(toString());
  }

  @Override
  public String toString() {
    return "Car [name=" + name + ", year=" + year + "]";
  }
}

package org.jspare.samples.api;

import java.util.Arrays;
import java.util.List;

import org.jspare.samples.model.Car;

public class CarApiImpl implements CarApi {

  @Override
  public List search() {

    return Arrays.asList(new Car("BMW 3 Series", 2017), new Car("Lexus RX 350", 2016));
  }
}

package org.jspare.samples.application;

import org.jspare.core.annotation.Inject;
import org.jspare.core.annotation.Resource;
import org.jspare.samples.api.CarApi;
import org.jspare.samples.model.Car;

@Resource
public class Consumer {

  @Inject
  private CarApi carApi;
  
  public void giveMeAllCars(){
    
    carApi.search().forEach(Car::print);
  }
}

Bootstraping, its time to start your java application

Bootstrap is the starting point of your application, through it you will set the standards and behaviors. Access the references for more information.


package org.jspare.samples;

import static org.jspare.core.container.Environment.my;

import org.jspare.core.container.Application;
import org.jspare.samples.application.Consumer;

public class Boostrap extends Application {

  public static void main(String[] args) {

    Application.run(Boostrap.class);
  }
  
  @Override
  protected void start() {

    my(Consumer.class).giveMeAllCars();
  }
}

Dont't worry!

Please refer to the documentation to better understand the conventions. See more

The above code are available here on Github.
Page.content:
First steps

Starting with JSpare Core Container

Dependencies

Follow the required dependencies for start with JSpare Core Container

Maven

<dependency>
	<groupId>org.jspare</groupId>
	<artifactId>jspare-core</artifactId>
	<version>2.0.0</version>
</dependency>
Gradle

dependencies {
    compile "org.jspare:jspare-core:2.0.0"
}

Structuring a project

Example basics of how should be the default structure of your project, later on we will deal with all the conventions.

  • org.jspare.samples Default package
    • model Package with models
      • Car.java Sample model
    • api API sample package
      • CarApi.java Interfaces of APIs
      • CarApiImpl.java Impl for CarApi interface
    • application The application impls
      • Consumer.java Class responsible for consume apis
    • Bootstrap.java Bootstrap of project

Abuse of components!

Write your applications using container, surely your application will get more organized and you were unpacking things.


package org.jspare.samples.api;

import java.util.List;

import org.jspare.core.annotation.Component;
import org.jspare.samples.model.Car;

@Component
public interface CarApi {

  List search();
}

Follow the convetions, it will help you!

The JSpare Core Container, have some conventions for help with your codding. Below you will see a convention for standard implementation of a component.



package org.jspare.samples.model;

public class Car {

  private String name;
  
  private int year;
  
  public Car(String name, int year) {
    super();
    this.name = name;
    this.year = year;
  }

  public String getName() {
    return name;
  }

    this.name = name;
  }

  public int getYear() {
    return year;
  }

  public void setYear(int year) {
    this.year = year;
  }
  
  public void print(){
    
    System.out.println(toString());
  }

  @Override
  public String toString() {
    return "Car [name=" + name + ", year=" + year + "]";
  }
}

package org.jspare.samples.api;

import java.util.Arrays;
import java.util.List;

import org.jspare.samples.model.Car;

public class CarApiImpl implements CarApi {

  @Override
  public List search() {

package org.jspare.samples.application;

import org.jspare.core.annotation.Inject;
import org.jspare.core.annotation.Resource;
import org.jspare.samples.api.CarApi;
import org.jspare.samples.model.Car;

@Resource
public class Consumer {

  @Inject
  private CarApi carApi;
  
  public void giveMeAllCars(){
    
    carApi.search().forEach(Car::print);
  }
}

Bootstraping, its time to start your java application

Bootstrap is the starting point of your application, through it you will set the standards and behaviors. Access the references for more information.


package org.jspare.samples;

import static org.jspare.core.container.Environment.my;

import org.jspare.core.container.Application;
import org.jspare.samples.application.Consumer;

public class Boostrap extends Application {

  public static void main(String[] args) {

    Application.run(Boostrap.class);
  }
  
  @Override
  protected void start() {

    my(Consumer.class).giveMeAllCars();
  }
}

Dont't worry!

Please refer to the documentation to better understand the conventions. See more

The above code are available here on Github.

Page.title: Docs
Page.nav_message: Guideline for start with JSpare Core Container
Page._content:
• Get Started
  • JSpare Container
  • Contribute
  • Others

Content

  • Get Started
    Dependencies Structuring a project
  • JSpare Container
    Environment Overview Bootstrap Configuration Container Components & Resources Injections & Injectors
  • Contribute
    Issues / Bugs Changelog
  • Others
    Architecture Dependencies Resolutions

Get Started

Starting with JSpare Framework

The first thing you always ask yourself is how to start using a framework, you'll see that with Jspare there's nothing out of this world, let's start with dependencies ...

Dependencies

Follow the required dependencies for start with JSpare Framework

Maven

			<dependency>
			<groupId>org.jspare</groupId>
			<artifactId>jspare-core</artifactId>
			<version>2.0.0</version>
			</dependency>
Gradle

			dependencies {
			compile "org.jspare:jspare-core:2.0.0"
		}

Incredible, you added our dependency and now where we can start, following this document we will try to be logical and consistent with the explanations, let's understand how the ship works and then fly ok?


JSpare Container

Understanding the core of our application

Keep calm, we are working!

Soon this content will be available

Contribute

The JSpare more powerfull

Issues / Bugs

You can report any issue or bug, just go to our github and register a new task, make sure our team and above all the community will help you. For our growth it is fundamental that we are always united with the whole community.

Please register your issue at: GitHub / Issues

Changelog

Access the Changelog Page and track all of our backlog and predictions of new features and fixes.

Others

Behind of framework

Architecture

We are writing an article with all the detail behind development. Sign up and do not miss updates.


Dependencies Resolutions

Our entire project was thought to be the purest and simplest solution in terms of container and control inversion.

We have a short list of dependencies that are part of our development, know a bit more because we use some of these technologies.

Get Started

Starting with JSpare Framework

The first thing you always ask yourself is how to start using a framework, you'll see that with Jspare there's nothing out of this world, let's start with dependencies ...

Dependencies

Follow the required dependencies for start with JSpare Framework

Maven

			<dependency>
			<groupId>org.jspare</groupId>
			<artifactId>jspare-core</artifactId>
			<version>2.0.0</version>
			</dependency>
Gradle

			dependencies {
			compile "org.jspare:jspare-core:2.0.0"
		}

Incredible, you added our dependency and now where we can start, following this document we will try to be logical and consistent with the explanations, let's understand how the ship works and then fly ok?

Post.title: Hello World
Post._content:
Welcome to [Hexo](https://hexo.io/)! This is your very first post. Check [documentation](https://hexo.io/docs/) for more info. If you get any problems when using Hexo, you can find the answer in [troubleshooting](https://hexo.io/docs/troubleshooting.html) or you can ask me on [GitHub](https://github.com/hexojs/hexo/issues).

## Quick Start

### Create a new post

``` bash
$ hexo new "My New Post"
```

More info: [Writing](https://hexo.io/docs/writing.html)

### Run server

``` bash
$ hexo server
```

More info: [Server](https://hexo.io/docs/server.html)

### Generate static files

``` bash
$ hexo generate
```

More info: [Generating](https://hexo.io/docs/generating.html)

### Deploy to remote sites

``` bash
$ hexo deploy
```

Ok, deu certo. teste.

More info: [Deployment](https://hexo.io/docs/deployment.html)
